posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I'm as much of an /out/ist as I am a /k/nigger, I might be able to give you some general advice.
You're wise beyond your years for going ultralight for a SHTF kit. A lot of people tend to overestimate how much their body can handle, which will break you in the long run. I would never recommend going full ultralight, though, most of that gear will not stand the wear and tear of SHTF.
/k/, and /out/ for that matter, don't have any agreed upon load out. Someone in Nevada and someone in the Pacific Northwest will have completely different considerations to make.
No way is that list under $500 anymore, I'm sorry zoomers, the other generations failed you. Some things I'd recommend swapping out to make it more reasonably priced.
>shelter
If it's solely for SHTF you can get by with an ultralight bivvy from amazon, it will keep you mostly warm and dry, is faster to set up, lower profile, and a lot cheaper. The biggest draw back with a bivvy and single walled tents in general is the condensation from breathing will leave the inside damp in the morning. If you also plan on recreational camping, get a 2 person tent, for comfort, and so you can take your GF camping, bitches love camping.
>pack
For a pack, I recommend an Osprey in the 40-50 liter range, good quality and a great value, especially if on sale. Downside is it will weigh about twice as much as an UL pack, but will easily triple the lifespan.
>sleeping pads
For sleeping pads, I prefer inflatables, they take up less volume, but I have had one fail on me before and it was a miserable couple of nights. A closed cell foam is reliable and you can strap it to the outside of your pack if there isn't enough room.
>mess kit
For your mess kit, a brs 3000, a folding utensil, a titanium 750ml pot, and a large fuel canister will nest together nicely and cost less than the stove that is in that list.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57072600
>https://lighterpack.com/r/776crf
frog toggs are bullshit - they don't have the durability you need for any kind of distance moved through the wilderness. Use a US military issue poncho to replace the frog toggs and external pack waterproofing material.

Freezedried foods are tasty and light - but for the cost and size they're seriously lacking in calories and demand giant amounts of water to prepare. Unless you're in an area you know water sources for or which is extremely water abundant it's better to skip those and the stove and to just carry calorie dense food you can eat cold like peanut butter, trail mix, jerky, etc. so you can eat till you're just barely not hungry during the day and that you're pleasantly full before you sleep. That lends you the ability to leave the stove behind as well if you're willing to eat cold food - even if you do the "leave no trace" principle. This also cuts down on scent and other potential target indicators like infra red light from a fire or lingering thermal trace on any cooking site and equipment.

Additionally, if you're shooting for maximum travel on minimum weight you're going to want to sleep during the day when it's warmer (lighter sleeping system) and walk at night (moving around will keep you warmer, and you can moderate your pace and layers in tandem to avoid excessive cycling of water or carrying unnecessary material) - just don't get lost or carry a garmin in the weight you saved by cutting down your sleep system. You won't get nice views as you move, but you'll be more subtle, have a less crowded trail, and move faster which are all good things if you're in a situation that's more /k/ than /out/.

Another consideration completely missed by this list is internal organization of the pack, this is important for minimizing time taken in temporary halts. big empty bags without mesh pockets are dumb

this list is built for a physical invalid walking on meticulously curated trails on dayhikes or 1.5 day hikes.

>>57072600
>Is this the ultimate load out save for weapons?
No.
>Ok, just kidding, seriously, does /k/ even have a load out agreed upon?
Also no, but I think we can all agree that's not it.

That list is a pretty good UL backpackers set up but SHTF entails some pretty fucking big contextual differences. What might be just an inconvenience on a leisure trip could be life threatening in the event of shtf.
For example, a good shtf loadout will probably emphasise durability more than most ULers and you'll definitely want a more serious first-aid kit than what he carries.

There's also the fact that not everyone's shtf is the same - do you expect to be using this pack to crash in a hotel for a few weeks while the gov cleans up after a natural disaster, is it to get you overland to your parent's farm because your city's locked down due to half a dozen cases of pneumonia on the other side of the country, will you be regrouping with the rest of The Wolverines and conducting a hit-and-run insurgency against the occupying government or scavenging for bottlecaps in post-nuclear apocalypse? Obviously gear for one shtf might be useful in others but you'll want to tailor shit to what you think most likely.

Use his gear as a starting point, check reviews for any durability concerns and consider stumping up something heavier if that's the case, invest in a more serious FAK and then actually start using it. You can buy new gear in the future but you're better of getting some experience in the meantime rather than getting bogged down in the details looking for things to be perfect from day 1.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57082620
Thank god I asked.
Thankfully there are a fuckton of options that people will argue about endlessly

Lets instead talk about some basics:
>Ankle support.
You want it, period.
It will save your ankles in a literal sense from a mistep, and makes it easier to step on uneven surfaces.
Don't go for some sort of "trail runner" with your bugout boots.
You are intending to carry weight and go distances with them.
That specific type of hiking is common and many a boot is made around that premise.

>Weight
In short, don't go for work boots on this.
You have to be able to hike with those things.

>Fit
Fit is damn near everything.
A good fit will not let your feet rub around and will support your foot properly. a pack of mole skin in your first aid kid will let you deal with blisters, but a properly fitting set of boots that are broken in should not wear out your feet like that unless you are going a long way.
>Breaking them in
Breaking in whatever boots you buy is essential. That is as simple as wearing them about your day for a week if you are actively moving around outside the house.
They will not flex and move with your feet properly until they are worn in.

Whatever you get, go for something waterproof since you deal with a climate that can snow in the winter. You will want to keep water out of your boots.
Also when using them for the love of god don't wear the same socks in them without washing said socks somehow.
That is how you get blisters and otherwise fuck up the skin on your feet.
>Breaking in your feet
If you are not used to walking all day, when you start to actually use those boots for real it is gonna hurt at the end of the day and in the morning.
Basically your feet swell up on the bottom and then they dislike having weight put on them.
This will go away and your feet will "harden up"
The easy way to minimize the pain is simply to spend an hour with your feet/legs propped above your head to drain the lymphatic fluids out.

LOL no. I just spent a month trekking over extremely rough terrain with a 25 lb pack in trail runners with no ankle support (Salamon Alphacross) and they were perfect. I even had a pair of hiking boots with me that I only wore on summit days or crossing high passes because I couldn't attach crampons to my trail runners.

That said, I probably wouldn't recommend trail runners for shtf because they lack the durability to last when going over really rough terrain or boulder hopping. The upper started to peel away from the sole on my Salamons at about the 4 week mark. I don't think they're built to handle the lateral forces.
Still, the weight savings were more than worth all the other tradeoffs up until that point. You have more agility on them and that balances out the lack of ankle support if you don't have shitty weak ligaments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57072600
You should 1000% carry a small water filter, just not tablets. A sawyer squeeze mini, or something. They are cheap, extremely lightweight, bomb proof, and quick. Get smartwool briefs, or something with a high merino wool blend, theyre worth every cent. Also, you should get some proper trail running shoes or light boots. Road runners will disintegrate if you're moving through rugged terrain.

Besides that, I would say you really need to try using some of this stuff in the field. A common folly is people overcorrecting when it comes to weight reductions (see "stupid light"). Comfort and convenience are really important. Many people carry 2-person tents even when solo. The weight increase is tolerable relative to a 1P, and the extra space makes a HUGE difference especially when you have wet gear and need to spread out a bit. Also, a bigger cooking pot. I carry the TOAKS 1600ml. I can actually cook meals in it, and also in a "bugout" situation you could boil a lot more water. An nice inflatable sleeping pad is a big investment, and it is one more thing to break/pop, but good sleep is priceless. Those foam pads dont work for many people, I do use them. These are all just suggestions, you may be perfectly happy with all of this gear. I can tell you've done a lot of research and have made good choices (S-tier pick for packliner btw), but there really is no substitute for just getting out there. Theres a saying in the thruhiking community "hike your own hike". Everyone wants/needs different things to be comfortable. The suggestions Ive made, if implemented thoughtfully, represent probably less than a pound of pack weight.

P.S. A lightweight roll top dry bag is a great thing to have. Mine weighs 2.5oz. Can be a life saver.


>inb4 reddit spacing

>>57086730
>>57086737
>>57086300
>>no lifestraw
>A lifestraw is basically a water filter you can drink through. (picrel)
Yeah, let me just stick my head down into the stream every time I want to drink or fill my waterbottle with dirty, unfiltered water so it's not contaminated. Also, I now how to unscrew the lid of my water bottle to stick the straw in every time I want to take a drink. And, as far as I know, incompatible with camelbaks/water bladders.
Lifestraws are a shit. Get a Sawyer or Katadyn, Sawyer Mini is probably the best option for OP.

However, be aware that water filters DO NOT protect against viruses. That's not usually a problem for backpacking (the main things we're concerned about innawoods are bacteria or protozoa - waterborne viral illnesses are traditionally only a concern for people visiting the third-world, although it's now becoming an issue in some of the more crowded campsites and would also be an issue if you're camping near farmland) but it is something you need to consider for a SHTF loadout. Whether it's floods, bombs or simply inadequate maintenance there's a lot of shit that can go wrong with water+sewerage systems in a disaster and the instant it does you've got shit and viruses contaminating water sources. And the influx of evacuees/inexperienced 'preppers' will no doubt shit up (literally) even backcountry water sources.
I use a Steripen when camping because it's effective against viruses, bacteria and protozoa, as well as being much faster than any other option. Kinda fragile though

If you're relying on a water filter then you really ought to combine it with a chemical purifying agent of some kind. Unfortunately you can't use a chemical agent on it's own because most are ineffective against protozoa (Aquatabs and iodine will do shit against crypto, Aquamira works but only if you leave it for four hours).
Any water filter that says it'll protect against viruses will be a slow-ass bitch to pump through and clog extremely easily.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57072600
>load out agreed upon?
I don't know what works for you and what works for one guy won't work for the other.
>I’m a newbie looking to buy this all overnight
Here's what I did after the military. I wrote down my normal packing list, crossed off all of the shit I wouldn't need, added shit that would be a concern if venturing out on my own that otherwise wouldn't be a problem while part of a well supplied army, and then individually researched each bit of kit to ensure I was getting the best tool for my specific needs.
Consider what your plans would be, where you'd go, the environment, etc. Then watch some videos and read up on bushcraft. I recommend Dave Canterbury.
If you do this correctly (and then practice your skills) you'll end up with the lightest pack possible I promise you that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57095879
What are some lesser known items people miss in their kits?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57096593
One I didn't even consider until recently is a slingshot.
Very light, ammo everywhere, and can reasonably and silently kill small game.
Also,
>traps
Snares are super light and versatile. You can catch damn near any animal.
>frog spear
Also light and you can find a stick to use as a handle. Useful for dispatching small game and such.
>wet bag
Useful for moving water, keeping your shit dry, or just carrying shit around without taking your whole ruck if you have a camp of sorts. Not sure why I've seen so many people not have one in their kit.
>METAL (not plastic) water bottle/canteen/etc
Some people buy those fucking lifestraw type bottles or have anything but a simple uninsulated bottle that can be boiled
>folding saw
I personally don't carry a tent and never have. If I'm in such a shitty environment where I can't make a shelter, I'll need to rough it in a bivvy sack because clearly I don't have time to fuck with a tent either. Otherwise, a folding saw is extremely useful for processing wood and such
>A proper bushcraft knife
Not a pocket knife, not a tactical knife.
>whetstone
Gotta keep your tools sharp. Innawoods there's no walmart.
Anything else IMO is dependent on your specific environment or just something I'm forgetting.
But my philosophy is to have tools to get food, make shelter, and stay warm. If you have the tools that will allow you to make the things that you need, you won't need anything else or if you're so inclined you can bring whatever else as a luxury.
Again, the downside is if you're being pursued or whatever you don't have time to do a lot of this but that's where being ok with roughing it comes into play for me. Most of my "camping" experience has been absolutely miserable as a result but it also made me accept that there are lots of things I don't actually need and also realize that SHTF is gonna suck absolute shit.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57101563
Diameter: 1" to 1.3"
Length: 72" to 90". 80" is a good length if you're of average height.
Wood type: Ash is best, and also most traditional. Hickory is popular, but doesn't like to flex as much. Don't use any other type of wood.
Iron or steel: You could make it a spear, I guess? Or you could make a shod quarterstaff, with a short metal cap or spike at each end, like a small Greek sauroter.

>>57091078
They arguably never left it to begin with. At the start of the 20th Century, Russia was STILL a feudal state under Tsar Nicholas II. They had no real industrial base to speak of, over 95% of the population were rural farmers, many of them serfs. It was only during the rise of communism that they forcibly industrialized the country in a matter of a few years.
Imagine that for a moment. One day you're Ivan Ivanovich, rural dirt farmer. Every one of your forefathers has, since time immemorial, farmed this dirt plot for grain and raised goats. Tomorrow you and your habitually battered family are forced off your ancestral plot of land to make way for concrete commieblocks and smoke belching factories. You're all relocated to a cramped concrete cube in one of these already-crumbling towers and you're assigned a job producing machine parts on an assembly line in the factory built over your old farm. You're constantly told that you have been freed from the corrupt capitalist system and are now a liberated worker, and other such communist spiel. You of course don't have any idea what they're talking about, because you never read the communist manifesto (in fact, you were never taught to read) nor lived in a capitalist society. What do you even do other than go with the absurdity of your situation?
I'd say that this prolonged collapse of the Russian state will lead to that in the end, the feudal mindset of the average Russian was not prepared to enter post-industrial society, and both we and they have suffered for the consequences of it. When all is said and done, it's probably best to tear it all down and return them to their fields overall.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57100465
>NATO isn't going to declare war on Russia over a missile screw up

I agree, somewhat. I think NATO response depends on a number of factors

>Can it unambiguously be proven that Russia was the perpetrator of the attack?
>Were there any casualties?
>Does the attack appear to have been intentional or carried out with extraordinary recklessness (to the point of effectively being an act of provocation)?

I think that at least two of these three criteria are met, it would result in NATO retaliatory strikes. That doesn't necessarily mean WWIII erupts and the whole planet gets blanketed in nuclear fire though. A NATO retaliation could potentially consist of a one-off strike on the origin point of the attack such as having F-35s shoot down the planes or sink the ship that launched the missile. That way NATO can save face with a tit-for-tat, but still have wiggle room to avoid a full-scale nuclear war.

Fuck sake. Read the god damn Article 5 wording. Even had two missiles struck Romania and killed people there is nothing in Article 5 that states that the immediate response is full mobilisation and the attacking of Russia. It states that military action is the 'UP TO' part of the response. As in, the highest response possible. Article 5 is not a military 'attack move' to Moscow. It is about maintaining the security of the North Atlantic area. Which can mean fucking anything. Missiles over a nation? AA defences. Sanctions. Strongly worded letter. Thoughts and prayers. It does not mean an attack on Russia. Deaths or not. That's why the wording is worded as it is. To allow wiggle room for NATO to cuck out of getting involved. Regardless, the missiles just entered the air space which while against international law, isn't enough to fucking do anything ANYWAY.

Now had the missiles hit Palace of the Parliament when there were people there? Maybe something could be done but lmao.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57098786
>Can someone explain why Americans hunt squirrels?
They're essentially unregulated small game that breed like wildfire and have few natural predators. They're also destructive garden pests, harass birds (squirrels destroy nests for dray material and loot feeders), trash nut and seed crops, and are nearly as bad as rats if they get into grain storage. We hunt a LOT of small game over here; hunting has never really been a rich man's hobby. It's the norm for most rural communities.

>Are they pests over there?
They're pests in the US, though not the apocalyptic plague that shit like rabbits and hamsters have been elsewhere. In England American Greys are a destructive invasive species. Stuff like nutria and starlings are more of a genuine environmental problem in the States proper than squirrels.

>>57067056
Fit and finish, mean a proper 90 degree sharpened spine, not burr's on the blade,
heat treatment, properly sized and assembled rivets. fit and finish covers everything but the major manufacturing of the blade itself, and its primary bevel. Even how sharp it comes from the factory counts as fit and finish. A TRC apocalypse in m390 has amazing fit and finish, my bark river aurora scandi in CPM magnacut has amazing fit and finish. These knives feel better in the hand after 20 minutes making kindling, and fire steel strikes better on their spine, the convex edge they come with holds it edge longer in hard use vs a cheap V edge. I could go on, but if you choose the correct knife 3-400 isnt a silly amount to pay if you want the best.

Ok listen here, samefagging nigger: assuming your hypothetical knife (if you owned one) had a properly heat treated 60 HRC D2 steel blade (virtually unobtainable unless you go custom, D2 is primarily used in shitty factory made chinkblades today), a knife made under the exact same conditions utilizing an M390 steel (which has a much higher working hardness of around 63 HRC with a proper heat treat) is going to be around 30 times more wear and abrasion resistant, meaning it will retain, not only AN edge, but a razor edge, for much, much longer due to the insanely fine grain structure of modern powder steels.
Yes, it will be harder to sharpen a knife like that, but it you will also have to sharpen it exponentially less often.
The idea that an A2 steel blade can compete with an M390 blade in wear or corrosion resistance is like a chink trying to compete with an Aryan Giga Chad.

It's a 4% Vanadium and almost 1% Tungsten super fine grained powdered alloy, of course it's hard to sharpen. Those extremely hard carbides are exactly the reason it holds an edge for so insanely long.

The only down side is that it will work the belts down much faster compared to something like VG10 or even 3V, but with how little you have to sharpen it, it's not a problem at all. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57093561
Yeah I find it to be quiet neat
Batoning works fine
Blade holds a good enough edge
I live in moderate temperatures. In winter it only gets -13f/-25c here. I wrapped the handle in grip tape that's good enough. Also I tend to wear my gloves when I am out so the issue of an uncomfy handle never came up really.
I led my normie friends on a week long trip to Sweden where the bushman needed to take care of all sorts of tasks from gutting fish to tasks around the camp I.e. Chopping branches and clearing shrubs to we can hang our hammocks and establish camp sites
Producing fine kindling cooking etc. I even used it as an improvised hand fishing line holder and caught a number of fish which tasted really nice. Chopping off their heads is remarkably easy. It was a good time and I was honestly a little surprised since i didn't expect too much of that knife. On the other side I am planing on widening the hollow handle so it accepts hatchet handles.
Are there better knifes? Yeah! I don't think the bushman is the cream of the crop. But it is good enough and a whole lot of value for its price point.

Also since it is all metal I don't feel too bad modifying it to my needs. If I ruin it I can always just get another one.

I brought up sharpening because in my head having a sharpening stone is equally important to having a good knife. What use is having even a 2000 dollar knife if you can't maintain it. It will just become a useless lump of metal over the time

It's not even that cold anywhere in Ukraine (and hasn't been in 2022 or 2023 yet).
>>57099988
>fuel crystalizes
Diesel begins to gel and present a problem/risk at -9C. It's a serious problem past -15C. Even marginal warming helps with that, not to mention that there are anti-gel mixture or winter diesel (diesel without parafin). Winter diesel begins to gel/cloud at -40C.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57099988
In civilized countries the diesel doesn't crystalize until -40 nowadays, and every gas station sells fuel treatments for those stuck with summer blend in cold snaps. As you mention, kerosene or even gasoline blending is acceptable on old equipment.
Those pan heaters don't just help, they're necessary for engine starting in arctic weather. Even winter-weight oils become so viscous the starter motor can't achieve proper RPMs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57066320
If you like overbuilt, you could aways go for Cold Steel´s contract Demko stuff that has his designs and his tri-ad lock. Cold Steel had some pretty cringe marketing campaigns but they´ve aways made solid knives. These Demkos are not really flippers though, and you mentioned that in your first post. Another suggestion along those lines is the Benchmade Mini-Adamas in CPM cruwear steel. The Axis lock flips like a maniac and it´ll be a better finished knife than the Cold Steel Demko ones, and it has a superior, deep carry clip.

The general problem with this "overbuilt" folders is not even size, but weight. Carrying a knife in the pocket makes every single ounce count a lot. The knife tilts a lot when it is heavier. I generally stay away from folders that weight more than 4 oz. Any heavier than that, I think it is more suitable for belt carry. Others will carry an 8 ounce knife in their pocket and forget its there.

I asked if you were planning on sharpening it yourself because of your choice of steel, this is an entire can of worms with many many variables. In the most basic of terms, the higher a supersteel is rated for cutlery, the longer it will retain its edge, and the harder it is going to be for a novice to sharpen. Edge retention and ease of sharpening vary dramatically between knife steels. But even a supersteel blade will eventually get dull. This aspect must be carefully considered, and it is often disregarded. There are other factors such as hardness and rust resistance, but these don´t matter much for folders.

posts.com:
>>57066740
Thanks anon. I dont want to actually sharpen my blade every other evening, so edge retention is crucial. But on the other side, steel doesnt need to be a total bitch to shatpen... weight is a viable consideration, thank you. What steels do you recommend? Elmax? S 30v?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57067015
Like I said, cutlery steel is a big subject, and every man has his own preferences and experiences. And there is aways new steels coming, with different properties, but the market is generally oriented torwards edge retention. Every year, some new cutlery supersteel comes along with the latest and greatest edge retention. When you've been doing this long enough, you will eventually stop chasing the latest steel of the hour. I do all my sharpening free hand, and over the years I found out there is a compromise when the knife takes too many passes to get the edge back. And I know I aways end up using my higher end knives less, in favor of knives I can sharpen more quickly. Between Elmax and s30v, I prefer s30v. I even remember when it was considered the latest supersteel. Sorry about textwalling you, anon. Should be more concise

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57098880
what you see on those Civivis is not Damasteel, but a Chinese imitation of it. real Damasteel (from the Damasteel company) is made with two powder metallurgical steels: RWL-34 (equivalent to CPM154) and PMC27 (about equivalent to 12C27/AEB-L). As good as it may look, at best it'll perform as good as a blade from only RWL34.
Meanwhile we know about the Chinese stuff that it contains 9Cr18 (equivalent to a 440B). The other steel I'd guess is something similar to 12C27.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57076997
Set up a target at 25 yards, set your rear sight to the 200 meter setting and use your sight tool to adjust the front sight post and drum until it’s zeroed. Then set the rear sight to the 100 meter setting and confirm the zero at 100 meters on paper or steel targets. Then you’ll be good to go. You can also adjust to the battle zero setting, aim for the belt on a man size target and you should hit it every time at various ranges.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Is it possible to replace entire army, navy and air force with drones?
1. air force
a. drones already can perform roles of bombers, cheap drones can carry simple, small bombs while reaper-alike can carry air-to-air and air-to-ground missiles
b. we know of at least one air-to-air combat where a fighter jet was destroyed by a drone; swarms of cheap, small kamikaze drones could easily down a multimilion-dollar advanced jet
2. navy
a. at least the british already have drone minisubs
b. main function of the navy is protection or destruction of naval resources, which can be easily accomplished by swarms of drone subs
3. army
a. boots on the ground can be replaced by armed big dogs
b. anti-infantry role is taken by chep drones with grenades
c. drone tanks are being developed: THeMIS for example, fitting them for artillery role is trivial.
4. drone weaknesses:
a. EW
- GPS MitM - countered by encrypted positioning channels, like in Galilleo system
- jamming - no real counter unless you pack a lot of technology into them to make them automated; there's at least possibility to not rely on GPS under jam by adding some weather sensors and accelerometers, with simple math to acquire position from last reliable GPS signal.
5. drone pros:
- price! multiple drones for a price of single manned vehicle + crew.
- size - unmanned means smaller, harder to hit

/k/, is it time for robot armies?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57097841
Same thing. You have your missile silo in orbit where everyone can see it and monitor it. Everyone can see it change its inclination in advance so it can pass over a target before it can hit it, and everyone can see the mirvs deorbit tens of minutes before they hit the atmosphere and then their target. There is no upside to having your missile silo in space compared to having it on the ground. It doesn't make your missile hit its target faster, it makes it so you can't protect your missile under meters of concrete and rock, can't perform maintenance on the missile because it's in space either.
It's not like the ship would open the bomb bay doors as it's flying above the target and the bombs fall, you need to individually deorbit each bomb, which would be very easy to observe, and would make it very obvious where the bomb is going. You also need to have the orbit go over the target, which means either waiting until the orbit's inclination and the targets latitude to align, or changing the ship's inclination, which costs fuel (you have a limited amount), is easily observable, and makes it very obvious what's about to happen. Assuming the target is on the equator and the ships orbit has zero inclination (ideal circumstances), you only have one deorbit window per 90 minutes (assuming ~350km orbit), so if you miss that window you need to wait another hour and a half, which is enough time for the nuclear war to be lost.
Things to keep in mind next time you read some retard claiming the x37b is a space bomber

For I novel I wrote that was just published last year, the mecha in this story have the height of mini mecha (3-4 meters) but when riding them, there are panels that allow you to control the limbs but this is how they work:

1. Mini mecha's arms controlled by human pilot's arms.

2. Mini mecha's legs controlled by legs of human pilot.

Pic related explaining how that works.

Now, what purpose do mini mecha have for combat applications in my novel? The first-generation Walgears were simply four-legged weapons platforms but they were outclassed by bipedal machines that also served the same purpose. Also, another benefit for mini-mecha is that they can be easily transported by C-5 Galaxies.

Now how was the building of mecha made possible for my story? An alien ship crash-landing in the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan in 1985. Four years after that, the Cold War turned into World War III after New York City and Moscow were struck with homemade nuclear weapons. This World War III lasted three years, ending with the splintering of the Soviet Union. Disagreements on how the world was to be restructured led to the world being divided into supernational unions with an organization calling itself the Gatekeepers of Knowledge, created by the scientific expeditions that studied the alien shipwreck in Afghanistamn, offering what they were able to develop from their research to help rebuild. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
China has been holding off on building new subs for a while.
They have been making a lot of new variants of old submarines in small numbers to test new technology, but they haven't committed to mass producing a Virginia/Ohio equivalent SSN or SSBN design yet.
They have two in the works and they have been quietly expanding their shipyard capability, but they haven't started production in earnest yet.
IMO this is because they likely believe that there isn't much point until they break out of the first Island chain, they likely want to massively expand their sub fleet after they have solved the Taiwan question, and they likely intend to base a lot of them on the eastern side of the Island.

For the more short range and litoral work that is likely to happen around China in the short term, Diesel submarines are a better investment.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57063598
.300 WM has better frontal surface, higher grain weights and is supremely flat shooting out to all ethical hunting ranges. Recoil is easily manageable and really isn't an issue in a high powered hunting rifle anyway.
Also .30 cal is the minimum caliber requirement for hunting big brown bears and bison in the Yukon and Alaska, so .300 WM is the ultimate do it all cartridge in pretty much every hunting situation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Buddy I never reply to posts but I’ll reply to yours.
1. Vortex is stupid and if you buy one you’ll feel like all those suburban idiots in their f150s with the stickers on the window
2. You probably don’t need the magnification you think you do. Moose and bear are gonna be close and a scope with a tiny field of view and fucked up eye relief is gonna be your nightmare
3. Find a leupold 2x-whatever 10 or 12 without a firedot reticle- it’s big and useless and obscures view at long range- maybe the make a vx5 2-12

If I were to choose a rifle for all of those I’d get a 338wm. Bigger holes and the bullets hold up better. If you’re worried about long as shots with an elk then you absolutely have to be worried about where that elk is gonna run after you hit him and how far he goes. If he goes into a ravine you’re fucked etc etc etc

For my money (not unlimited budget) I’d get a ruger m77 in 338wm. Tang safety for flare but not cause it’s better…
Leupold vx5 (no firedot or special reticle) in lowest mag to highest, probably 2-12. 1” tube with a 40mm+ bell.
So many things depend on your hunting scenario but if it were me I would prioritize low magnification optical clarity, controlled extraction (preferably entirely controlled feeding) and weight in the 338 range

Pic is a rifle with a vx6 ive used to kill things

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57087988

I've been hunting my entire life, and during my childhood in a family of 7 in Rural North Dakota, hunting season was genuinely a large source of our Meat throughout the year. Papa saved up for a 2nd-Hand chest freezer and we put it in our garage, to be stocked with pheasant, grouse, deer, and ducks throughout the year. We paid our local butcher in a portion of the meat to cut it and grind and package it to usability. In lean years we might not see a beef hamburger.

My father and I, and my brothers, would go out on bitter freezing mornings with our rifles in hand and a fistful of doe tags, knowing that getting our deer was a matter of familial preservation, hunting was not "sport", it was a normal task and duty of the household.

Which brings me to my point: my Father was a deeply religious, intelligent, but uneducated man. I was out hunting with him the December of my 12th birthday, and we were laying along the only rise in the local terrain somewhere 25 miles outside of Minot in -20f wind chill, waiting for the deer to start moving. I had a pair of Binoculars my Uncle had brought back from Vietnam, and my dad had his Ruger 30-06, which he diligently cleaned and cared for. It was so cold your fingers stuck to the gunmetal, and breathing on the scope while the rifle was shouldered instantly deposited a layer of frost.

I spotted a doe, just on the edge of one of the sparse treelines that delenated one field from another, looking around expectantly, contemplating a crossing. I whispered this to my father, who whipped off his glove and brought his scope to his eye. It was an easy shot for the old man, dead broadside, 200 Yards, wind to our backs. He sat there with his face to the rifle for a minute or more, then lowered his gun and worked the bolt, ejecting the shell and put his gloves back on.

CONT.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57089108
Being a child I could not really understand why we weren't digging the guts out of a deer to drop off to our Butcher, a deer that would no doubt be in my stomach sometime in January. So I asked:

"Papa, why didn't you shoot that deer?"

He replied:
"Buddy, sometimes I just don't feel like killing."

At the time I had no idea what he was talking about, but now that I'm older and he's long gone, I feel like he was trying to tell me something deep about his relationship with hunting, and nature in general. The hunter always has the choice to kill or let live, and sometimes making the choice to not kill is what it takes to appreciate the gravity of that choice.

I was working for the Wyoming Conservation Corps. If you're young and still in the area, you should consider it. 2 weeks out, 1 week home. Pay is garbage but they cover all your food while you're living in a tent working hard every day, and you go to beautiful places and meet cool people. And if you do a good job, what you build will last for hundreds of years.

In that same bighorn area was the only place I've ever seen fireflies in that part of the US. I met a guy with a PhD in insect biology, specializing in fireflies, who didn't know that they existed there. But it's beautiful, the dark mountainside at night, wildflowers in all colors, with fireflies dancing above. A memory I cherish.

The Americorps grants paid for my college education though, so I can't complain.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The Viet Cong has intelligence so extensive that they knew their each of their combatants on a first name basis. The approach is to draw out forces, clear the area, and then scatter and disappear as a fish disappears into water.

The guerilla is like a fish and the people are the water, the people and the surrounding environment are all they have. Many disappeared into hidden tunnels and caves, some into the local population. The guerilla doesn't need to target strongholds or bases, but instead brings the enemy into the mountains and wilderness. Supplies such as weapons and ammunition can be hidden in the wilderness, more or less obviously, as can anti-personnel traps and mines from salvaged supplies.

If hidden more obviously, such as in an abandoned camp or stronghold, guns and ammunition among other supplies can be rigged to explode and take out pursuing forces. If the enemy retreats having survived, they can be followed and pursued through the wilderness, as guerillas can rely on natural resources for survival and salvage enemy weapons, equipment, and ammunition.

The guerilla is essentially invisible, it could be anyone, and counter-insurgency cannot identify one from the other. They can only lock down civilian areas and interrogate civilians, which drains their morale and public support. The more brutal and intense the counter-insurgency strategy, the more the people support the insurgency, leading to surrender and guerilla victory.

>Wasn't the socialist party wildly unpopular in Japan for the most part?
It was
>what chance would have actually have especially considering Japan was basically a US vassal state?
You might be surprised when looking into it. The JSP was only founded in 1945, but if I can recall a related party, the Japanese Communist Party, we can go back and see something odd. The JCP was founded in 1922, and was then outlawed 3 years later. Throughout World War 2, it's members were imprisoned and subject to general repression. One was even found to be a Kremlin spy and was executed.
Then in 1945, following the defeat of Japan, the Allied occupation forces curiously re-legalized the Japanese Communist Party, along with many other far-leftist parties, which is where the Japanese Socialist Party came into the scene. And this occupation was entirely consisting of western soldiers, the Soviet Union decided it didn't want to place their captive citizens under the command of a US general like MacArthur.
I have to question why, at the beginning of the Cold War, would the US leadership allow these entities to continue to exist in Japan. Personally, I blame FDR as always. Fucking tyrannical faggot, if he hadn't happened to be in office during the war he'd never have such a reputation as he does. He'd be better known as a wannabe dictator who continually abused the systems of government to gain more power and colluded with our enemies (the Soviets). I'd throw in that he violated the rights of US citizens by throwing them in camps, but that was a wartime act, and I did say "if he hadn't been in office during the war"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57096726
In theory, sent back in time, for the explicit purpose of preventing the attack, yes. If you did a rolling takeoff from Pearl Harbor, with 16 Hellfires and full fuel, you'd have a combat radius of around about 300 miles; the attack was launched from about 200 miles out. The attack was launched in darkness and Japan did not have the ability to use radar for early detection or gun direction against aircraft. A Hellfire can penetrate >250mm of RHA equivalent; deck armor on Akagi was about 90mm.

Knowing the details of the attack in advance, with five helos you'd have one carrier each and then one more to attack afterwards, if you staged departure to arrive just before the aircraft were launched you could put twelve on each carrier and then two more on the sixth, aiming at critical parts of the flight deck, and aircraft already on deck. Coming in in the dark from 5mi distance with little warning while aircraft were being armed and refuelled, I think you would cause sufficient damage and disarray to mission kill the carriers before they launched.

But you've got no jet fuel or Hellfires on Hawaii, and no satellites for GPS so take that as you will.

Dude, a housecat can slice you open enough for you to bleed to death. Maybe if it's in a rage or fear, or a mother protecting her kittens, or a moment of catness and they forget to play gentle. I've taken some deep cuts, a couple that probably should have had stitches. I know people who have had stitches.

One buddy got clawed down his arm and had about 12 or 15 long gouges about a foot long. Over 100 stitches to get all that put back together after it was cleaned very thoroughly in an emergency room. It was an accident. His cat panicked over getting picked up in an encounter with a dog and just went apeshit on him, probably confused as to who or what was attacking him. A really sweet cat that never hurt anyone, including me, before or after. But, that one incident was insane. He lost so much blood the hospital considered giving him a transfusion.

I was carrying a young kitten one day, calm & cozy & half asleep in my arms. A dog ran into the room and jumped at him. He turned into a 2 pound demon, clawed his way out of my arms, up my chest, across my face and set all his claws into my scalp when he got on top of my head. I am here to witness that hurt like fucking hell, and took a couple days of cleaning & disinfecting all he wounds to make sure they could heal instead of turning infected.

I used to do feline rescue. The feral & semi-feral cats were less dangerous because I expected it and prepared for them to freak out, and still I've taken claws and bites through heavy protection. People I know in the community all have scars to help them remember their lessons. Housecats are to be respected. Larger cats eat humans because we are under them on the food chain. It's no fucking joke. They are fast and lethal.

I mean, I'll take your word for it, but I've owned 4 cats so far, and none of them were ever aggressive toward me with their claws. Even the feral stray male that my last cat made friends with would let me pet him sometimes without attacking me.

The worst I ever experienced was with this little female cat I had (who was very intelligent for a cat). If she wanted to get my attention, she'd sit right by me and stare at me. If a minute passed without me acknowledging her, she'd put her paw on my leg or arm. If I still didn't acknowledge her, she'd then slowly sink the claws on both of her front paws into my thigh. She would straight up escalate until I finally paid attention to her. She usually did this if she ran out of food/water or wanted the litter box cleaned.

Funny story: when this female cat was still a kitten, she had a bouncy ball she'd bat around the kitchen. One time it went under the oven, so I got it out using a wire coat hanger. I got the ball out, left the coat hanger on the floor next to the over, and went back to whatever I was doing. A few minutes later, I hear something metallic moving around the kitchen floor. Turned out that the ball had gone under the oven again, and the cat was pushing the coat hanger under the oven to get the ball out. She only needed to see me do it once to try it herself. I was fucking stupefied.

She was an extremely smart and clever cat. The smartest cat I've come across by far.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57087541
Don't get me wrong. I love & adore all cats of all sizes. This >>57080164 is me. I cannot emphasize how much that no cat should ever be declawed. They are crippled for life, and traumatized. I've lived with cats that have been mutilated like that and it's enraging and tragic. Because I love cats so much, I spent decades doing feral cat rescue and care. The reason I can tell stories like these >>57085846 is because I've handled so many cats in so many situations. A domesticated cat that has been raised in a safe and loving environment is almost incapable of harming people. They have to be treated very badly and endangered, and many will, even then, submit to torture and death before hurting a human.

But, there are accidents. And, some cats are not taught from a young age the difference between playing and playing for keeps. That's really all I was trying to say. The potential is there, but maybe I should have emphasized more strongly how incredibly rare such things are, and how unusual the circumstances need to be for it to happen.

>>57086889
>they usually dont mean to draw blood (though sometimes they do)
This.

A training trick here that helps a lot. If you're playing with a cat and they get too rough, immediately stop moving and say "OUCH! OUCH! OUCH!" Withdraw from play for a minute or so, then start again slower and more gentle. Cats figure it out quickly and temper their behavior. If they draw blood, even a small amount, touch their nose with a drop. Just a single small drop. Every cat that's ever lived with me never needed me to do that more than twice, and usually it's only once if at all. They learn fast. Just treat them as equals and don't freak out.

I still never understand how the fuck anyone expected the Germans to invade Britain after Dunkirk. It's like everyone just forgot the Royal Navy existed and the fact that it was still #2/#3 in the world, or at the very least certainly stronger than the combined German Navy/Airforce. The Germans could bomb the fuck out of London all they like, they were never going to actually get a significant number of troops there as that would require an amphibious operation which would be utterly slaughtered by the Navy while crossing the strait. And if they tried an airborne assault, even upon a bombed out and weakened London, it would still result in disastrous losses and wouldn't do anything to establish a foothold into England.

The only threat to England itself by that stage of the war was its supply ships being taken out by German U-Boats and causing shortages, but the Navy was large enough that it could defend the channel & hunt U-Boats, especially once America joined. I ain't saying England could've won by themselves, far fucking from it, but there's just no way they could have been invaded purely by Germany. Hell, even a combined German & Russian Navy probably still couldn't threaten England.

>Avionics systems, especially elderly ones, are rather finicky and need frequent maintenance
How do you maintain solid-state electronics?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57099436
modularity for quick replacement when needed or when the equipment's flight hour usage, pr general maintenance schedule recommends its replacement
the piece of equipment that needs maintenance is sent to whoever handles lifespan work, which could be in house, from the producer, or from a third party like you see with a lot of equipment on older aircraft like the 747
A major issue with legacy systems is that the company that produced them may no longer be and business and manufacturing new components requires finding drawings from 30+ years ago

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57099908

The term has evolved in the modern day. The need do diversify and build specialty vehicles to fit certain roles has broadened the classifications. While back in the 40s it would just be light medium and heavy tanks along with assault guns and the like there are far more dedicated and niche roles today. Basically they are all armored vehicles and the roles after that depend on their designated role so you get Tanks APCs SPGs IFVs and the like which are strict definitions. The best example i can think of is with music with something like the rock genre. Metal grunge classic and thrash are all subgenres but they are all still rock but you wouldnt call Slayer grunge because thats fucking stupid. The same way you couldnt call a BMP a tank.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57100001
You can't call a BMP a tank because it isn't a tank structurally (it isnt armored to resist antiarmor weapons) or doctrinally (its intended role is to carry infantry into battle safely, while a tanks intended role is to destroy the enemy in direct combat)
Meanwhile the terminator is built like a tank and its only intended purpose is to come into direct contact with the enemy and destroy them. You can subdivide it further and say it isn't a MBT because it doesn't have a tank cannon, but an MBT is just one kind of tank.

>>57083749
You're not going to conceal an SKS under a jacket, even with a folding abomination stock. The shortest you should go is 16", or just get a paratrooper model so you don't fuck up the crown. It's pretty obvious you don't know what you're doing so you probably will fuck the crown or chrome lining up. You can only cut it to the gas block, but you're going to cause cycling issues if you do. You'll have to concentricly thread the barrel to use a booster muzzle device, which can be quite long, so in the end you might as well have left a couple inches past the gas block to give adequate gas burn for reliable cycling.

My recommendation, don't do this shit. Buy a paratrooper rifle. Sell yours to make up the cost instead of ruining yours for yourself and making it un-sellable.

If you’re in the west you have no reason to choose and AK in 7.62x39 over an AR in 300 blackout (or 300HAMR)

And the whole point of 5.56 is it’s very low cartridge weight that translated to more rounds carried for the same weight. Everyone seems to forget that weight is a massive factor. No this doesn’t mean you should carry 1000rds of 22lr instead of 210 of 5.56, it just means if you’re moving up in weight, you better get something out of it. The weight increase of x39 over 5.56 comes from the last place you want it to, that offers next to nothing in terminal/external ballistics (a trajectory penalty, actually). All things considered, it is better that cartridge weight and energy come from powder/velocity than from bullet mass.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57097732
The nuclear winter models that predict widespread famine make several assumptions most of which are likely wrong.

The assumptions can be roughly grouped into two categories
>Nuclear Weapons will start lots of fires and every city will turn into a fire storm
Nuclear tests showed that nuclear weapons are much less likely to start a fire than one would expect. Although the "Flash" from the bomb is liable to cause fires but many of them are likely to be subsequently blown out by the over pressure from the blast wave. As for the fires which do start, while they are likely to be serious it is unlikely that they will create a firestorm on par with Hiroshima. Modern cities are significantly more fire resistant than Japanese cities circa 1945. I think it's worth noting that the bomb dropped on Nagasaki did not result in a firestorm.

>The Ash from the fires will be of a certain size and rise to certain levels in the atmosphere and stay there for extended periods
This is where the models really start having issues. They assume that the soot from all of the firestorms is going to be small enough to rise to the stratosphere and stick around for extended periods of time. The same models that predict nuclear winter also predicted that the Kuwaiti oil fires would cause similar effects during the first gulf war rather than the localized and temporary effects that were actually observed.

Not to say that nuclear war would be fun. Anyone in the blast zone or downwind is going to have a spicy time of things but it's hardly the world ending event people think it is. The actual issue most of the world population outside NATO/Russia/China would likely be political instability due to the economic collapse that comes with major financial centers being incinerated and the major powers being too preoccupied with imploding to continue offering foreign aid to the third world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57096960
>They aren't obsolete because they're completely useless - they're obsolete because the alternatives do the same thing better, for nearly the same price.
Every submarine requires a crew in the low hundreds, launches from calibrated depths, and toting around a nuclear reactor. Missiles are constantly in danger of exposure to an extremely aggressive corroding agent, and the launch signals are reliant on reception at considerable range.
Silos require a crew of ~10 for the entire field, plus a few contractors in a jeep to drive around to the silos every quarter, and only 2 to launch. Their supply lockers will last for over a year with minimal crewing. The missiles are sealed in a climate-controlled, EMP shielded, and very heavily-armored tube with no salt and very limited water exposure. They're auto-calibrated on a weekly basis with no influence from water motion. They can fire from a 30+ degree tilt after a strike and still hit the target, and those were the <de>classified tests. Communication is near-instant rather than relying on encrypted ELF in a combat posture. If the phone lines to the armed and ready to fire missiles are cut, the missile goes into dead man's hand status and launches on its own in a few hours unless specifically overridden. More importantly, a field can ripple launch some or all of its warheads depending on the appropriate response, and still be well-hardened enough to soak up vastly more firepower to disable than the sub.. which is now dead. The sub has to alpha strike with the first shot, because there likely won't be a second. The land site can launch a counterforce attack with enough MIRVS to launch a second counterforce or a countervalue attack afterwards. The whole reason we agreed to SALT in the first place was that it limited both sides to either counterforce or countervalue, not ride the fence. It's out the window, and we have a senile old commie who wants them russkies deed signing the checks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57080094
I want to like it, but the trade offs don't add up to an overall benefit.

Pros:
>low recoil
>higher capacity
>ability to penetrate soft armor when using specialty ammo

Cons:
>does not consistently penetrate within the minimum FBI requirement of 12-18", in fact consistently stops just short of 12"
>kiss expansion goodbye, the round is too skinny, only expands 1/5th of the time if using hollowpoints and doesn't even get thay wide
>thus, you now rely on the stars aligning for tumbling or fragmentation to happen as your main wounding mechanism (it doesn't often happen)
>round is too light, doesn't penetrate light barriers like windshields without extreme deflection (if it even manages to penetrate)
>specialty 9mm ammo can penetrate soft armor anyway, and leaves a bigger hole when it continues through

If you're adopting it you're taking on those trade offs. Ultimately I don't think it's a good all around defense/duty round.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57080094
5.7 is a meme out of a handgun length barrel.

It's advantages in a handgun are :
- greater capacity
- lower recoil
- flatter shooting

IMO, none of those things are enough to justify using a 5.7 over 9mm, 45acp., 40S&W (which I think are the three most common handgun calibers).

Capacity : for any (non-criminal) civilian, 6 rounds is going to be enough to solve virtually any situation they end up needing their pistol for. Anything over that is just frosting. The low end of standard for 9mm full size pistols is 15 rounds. 5.7 usually boasts 20 or so. Realistically, what situation is going to be solved by 20 shots that wasn't going to be solved with 15?
Reduced recoil : for some shooters this is going to be nice. Some. But these are people who are already recoil adverse. Frankly if you can't handle 9mm, you've probably got some kind of disability or ailment (muscle/nerve condition, arthritis, whatever) and I don't think the reduction in recoil is going to matter as much as going to an even lighter caliber, or finding a gun that fits their hands better. I could be wrong there, and it could be substantial enough, but that's only going to be for a very small segment of shooters.
Flatter shooting : Realistically, this simply doesn't matter at realistic self defense ranges. If you're at a range where flatter shooting matters, I don't think you're at self defense ranges anymore. And if you are, why don't you have a goddamn rifle in the woods?

Now, if you think 5.7 is fun and you like it an you just want it? Guess what? 100% perfectly valid reason for having it and using it. It's good enough to get the job done. Have fun.

BUT, don't try and argue 5.7 is superior enough to justify it over a basic bitch 9mm for your average law abiding citizen. It isn't. Simple as. Be honest. You want 5.7 for some other reason. It's very likely a valid reason. But don't lie and say "It's superior!". It isn't. Don't be dishonest, either with us or yourself.

>>57080932 (You)
>>57080691

You may not believe me, but there is a way to make Fallout 4 into a good game.
It's by running Fallout 4 in Survival Mode with A StoryWealth mod pack and with the added Personal Vertibird mod.

About A Storywealth:
Setup is via Nexus and Vortex. There are 360+ mods that add 30+ High-quality long quests (tens of hours), a ton of bug patches and fixes, and 4 major campaigns (dozens of hours) - Tales of the Commonwealth, Thuggysmurf mods, and Sim Settlements 2 (SS2). SS2 functionally alone makes FO4 an entirely new game and one that doesn't suck. Thuggysmurf mods either replace or augment the entire main campaign, depending on how you want to play the game. I personally use version 104.

The survival mode that comes with this mod collection is savage. You must drink, eat, and sleep else you take damage; infections are real and common, bleed damage / break damage occurs, etc. Nasty.

About personal vertibird:
With no fast travel in survival mode, the game is difficult. You'll be local to Sanctuary and a few other places until you've sufficiently progressed to getting blueprint + parts for a vertibird. Once you have a vertibird, you can use it as a way to travel (30 minute max travel time to cross the map). Get into a pinch? Call in air support. Settlement under attack? Load up your 4-6+ companions and become a QRF, dropping into a combat zone with battle-hardened troops.

Bottom line: A Storywealth + personal vertibird gets you a settlement building, hardcore survival-focused FPS RPG with newly written main quests and oodles of new functionality. Turning off fast travel and using the personal vertibird is game changing - nothing like walking to new places and calling in a QRF team when things get hairy. Survival is not guaranteed. For me personally, the act of building settlements, securing food / water / shelter, getting settlers, and then battling disease and raiders is truly rewarding and a real experience to behold.

posts.com: Pic related, plus the shotgun-specific perks "Shotgun Surgeon" and "And Stay Back", is just fucking UNFAIR. Shotgun Surgeon allows you to ignore 10 DT, using 12g flechette ammo ignores another 6 DT, and even if you can't penetrate their armor, And Stay Back gives a knockdown chance that is calculated for each projectile meaning you're almost guaranteed to knock down any enemy within the first three shots and potentially multiple enemies with single shots if they're bunched up. You can then sprint up to them and blast their fucking heads off at point blank range like it's a goddamn mob movie. Against enemies with less than 12 DT, along with Better Criticals using standard ammo, it gives an utterly absurd 650 DPS, and you can mow down groups of up to 4 standard Legion/NCR/Fiends in less than a second. Against power armored opponents or robots, it does similarly ridiculous damage when using Pulse Slugs. And with all of this, its VATS cost is similar to most pistol weapons. The only true downside is its very fast weapon degradation, but hey, that's what weapon repair kits are for.

>>57098303
Okay you're obviously a dumb-dumb but I will humor you and attempt to give you some serious feedback. This isn't some pussy game for consolelets like you apparently think it is, it's Fallout 1, the wasteland is going to eat you alive if you don't pick your battles more wisely. Survival determines how far away you spawn from random encounters, after about level 50 it's a dump stat however. 10mm is a good early gun but guns 101 isn't actually that high and you'll get fucked over trying to attack groups of enemies until your have the armor and/or hit points to eat multiple melee attacks per turn. You should run from most random encounters anyway in FO1, the loot isn't usually worth it.

>killian asks me to do the quest to bug gizmo's desk or something
>did it on my last playthrough and don't want to again, say no
>he becomes hostile

Literally have never had this happen on my multiple playthroughs, either your character's speech is so low you're tanking NPC dispositions every time you speak, or you're absolutely full of shit.

>i tried fallout 2 and couldn't find vic the trader literally fucking anywhere

He's in the SECOND TOWN YOU COME ACROSS. Most people find that by accident and even if you don't, this isn't like some Bethestard game from drooling troglodytes where one objective always follows the next and all problems lead to a dungeon of assholes that need killing. There are about 3-4 different ways you can get led to the location of Vault 15, almost as if non-linear quest design was some kind of defining hallmark of the fallout series or something.

Not saying the games don't have lots of flaws but the ones you mentioned are legitimately a skill issue. But if you're really struggling, get on a caravan, either in the Hub in FO1 or Redding in FO2, and just do nothing as your caravan cleaves through high level enemies, then grab the guns of everyone that dies. Instant profit, unless you get incinerated by mutants but that doesn't happen that often.

>>57099697
Not sure there's really a straight equivalent, and not many mixed ones either. I know the Neo-Assyrians at least were fond of forced displacement and dispersing conquered peoples about their empire to help break up attempts at rebellion. >>57099734
Mer tend to be broadly eastern (yes, including Khajiit, they are elves by lore), and while there are a few far eastern ideologies among the Dunmer, I find them far more analogous to the Near East. Akavir is more Asiatic, but less is known of them beyond than legend and hearsay. The Altmer are somewhat based on the Chinese though IIRC, but as with every race and nation in TES it's a fusion of many different things.
To elaborate on part of what I mean here, Veloth is nearly a 1 to 1 equivalent to Moses, his leading the Chimer out of Summerset and to their promised land of Morrowind and all. Nerevar is an incarnation of many saviors throughout the Bible, from Joshua in his war against the Canaanites (or in this case, the Dwemer) to David or even the Judges. The Nerevarine has similar equivalents, Jesus is an obvious pick, but one could say he's also closely based on Elijah or Elisha, prophets who were persecuted by the pagans who had supplanted the worship of God in Samaria/Northern Israel. In fact, I'd say the Nerevarine's later disappearance is somewhat close to Elijah being taken into Heaven in body and soul, technically not having died.
The actual morality of their Temple and associated factions of course differs, and there are some more eastern concepts in there too, but these strike out at me the most.
As for the Redguards, it's sort of a mix of all of them. There are two factions within Hammerfell after all, one was based on the Black Panthers as I recall.

posts.name: A2Grip
posts.com:
/arg/ Tasks of the month for Feb-2023
Maintenance-
Consistency is the core of precision, when was the last time you checked torque and witness marked your scope rings and mounting interface?
> Do you have a mark of some sort to help you indicate your scope is rolling in its rings?
> If your turrets don’t lock have you marked their zero position and do you check in your firing sequence?
> Do you have the torque specs recorded for your accessories and a way to torque these components in the field?
Everything will try to walk off your gun from use, transportation and the trip that happens when you take your rifle somewhere outside of a pelican case. You better have a plan to fix some of these things innafield.

Skill Sustainment-
Target: 9x9” Plate or similar paper
Rounds: 1-3 rounds
Equipment: SPR
Walk back to 300yd. Build a stable improvised position with your supports of choice, get on target and close your eyes
Action: Upon buzzer open eyes, flip safety off and acquire the target and deliver one hit to the plate or paper. Call your time, Add 1 second for each dropped shot.
Total times (Time+dropped penalty):
>Cold 5 sec = par
>Warmed up 4 sec = par
>3 and below = cooking it
Record your times and experiment with supports on your spr.
Improvement-
Bipods are excellent but their applicability outside of urban areas or manicured shooting areas can be dubious at best. You should get in the habit of each range session trying a new position, support or hold at various distances after you warm up. Aside from the support your two-point sling offers work on some alternative supports. At your outdoor range see how effective you are wrapping the sling around a vertical post. Practice sitting Indian style bladed towards target and supporting elbows with your daypack. Try a simple L support with your off hand against a post or barrier. Building these stable positions rapidly will improve the accuracy and precision of your shots in the field.

Zugzwang. No matter what Russia does/did, they were in a bad spot:
>Attack immediately: Troops aren't trained (especially manoeuvre troops), attacking into entrenched enemy, lacking equipment and supplies like they used to have, losing troops you need for future defense, etc..
>Attack later: Give Ukraine more time to replenish forces and build defenses, trajectory favors Ukraine long-term, make it harder to ever achieve objectives, not leveraging any Russian strengths.
>Wait to be attacked: Cede initiative completely. No readily observable means to win war. Allows Ukraine to take maximum advantage of superior western equipment and build forces.
>Etc...
I like to clown on Russia and their stupidity as much as the next man, but there was no "good" options, just a series of bad ones. They are repeating EXACTLY what they did after retreating from Kyiv. They were warned they'd take bad casualties and they should wait and constitute their forces but they attacked with everything they had instead. What happened? Initial headway at places like Izyum, Sievierodonetsk, etc.. followed by stagnation and then an eventual counterattack by Ukraine that has far more success. Ukraine gets stronger and Russia gets weaker. This is like watching an animal get strangled by a Boa constrictor. Little thrashes, bites, etc.. but every time the animal fights it gets a little weaker and the Boa's grip get s a little tighter.

>>57091093
Churchill was focused on (somehow) dividing Europe into mutually overlapping spheres of influence based on meaningless fractions. How can you share a sphere of influence with your enemy? Churchill wanted the West to have a 10% say in how Romania was run, but what the fuck does that even mean? The answer is "nothing". It's utter nonsense that doesn't even work on paper.
Meanwhile, FDR got Stalin to declare war on Japan in exchange for giving him a bunch of shit *he already had*. Stalin was going to turn Eastern Europe into Soviet puppet states regardless. By getting Stalin to sign an agreement that said, "ok, you can have it, but you got to hold free elections there," FDR made sure that when (surprise, surprise) Stalin didn't hold election, the following would happen:
1. The West does the surprised pikachu face and all the blame for Soviet imperialism would fall on the Soviet imperialists.
2. The Soviet occupation of Eastern Europe (which again was always going to happen because it had started before Germany even surrendered) would be delegitimized because Stalin had broken the agreement.
3. We could point and say, "See? This is what the Soviets will do to us all, if we let them. They can't be trusted, they can't be reasoned with, they can only be stopped."
4. If anyone in Western Europe was on the fence, they'd pick our side because we gave peas a chance. If anyone was seething about "muh self-serving nonalignment, blah blah blah, anglo-dominated world" they realized they have a choice between sometimes feeling they're under America's thumb or always having a NKVD pistol pressed against their skull. Hell, if you join NATO and the US tries to pull some bullshit, you can tell them to fuck off because everything requires unanimous consent.
FDR was laying the groundwork for the post-war system which eventually led to breakup of the USSR. Churchill was busy trying to trick Stalin into giving the West a 20% stake in Bulgaria when we’d take 15.

Good public transit doesn't eliminate cars, it gives an alternative option to them and makes the experience of driving cars better.

Lots of people who know with certainty they just plan need to go between two high-traffic areas can use transit without any inconvenience. A normal bus, without even any doubling up rows, can comfortably carry 20-40 people, which means a single full bus gets 10-40 of that image's cars off that road so the people who actually need to drive can go faster.

Furthermore, good transit makes walking around cities far more convenient and cheap than eg having to take lyfts and ubers, gives you the choice to not have to pay for a car if you don't want to by giving you alternatives, is a crucial resource for poor people because lacking a car or having fucked up car is financially devastating for keeping a job, and reduces deaths by drunk driving and accidents due to buses and other transit having stellar safety records. Good public transit's based af even if you have zero plan to use it yourself.

> you are forced to observe their path, their schedule, and their speed
In the era of smart phones, this isn't a problem - literally all map directions apps will build you a max speed itinerary, optimized according to your demanding specifications (or if you don't care, something that's probably optimal anyways for most people) that will get you anywhere in a major city at any hour to where you're going. It's unironically great, we live in a very different era than the pre 2010s "go online and download bus schedules and carry around a notebook with time charts"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Jammers don't work, the reason being that even consumer drones have anti jamming features built into them.
>auto return
>ranged designation
>AI targeting
I can designate a target at 100m, my drone can path to that target without any external signal, and hover over the target based on either the original area designated of the visual signature of the object- there simply isn't a signal to jam.
The other problem is that the power of the jammer must be exponentially greater than the signal of the drone. A drone could simply fly over the effective range of the jammer
Drones can triangulate the location of a jammer from many times further away than the jammers effective range if the jammer is active, the jammer gives it's own position away when used.
The cost of jammers is also very high compared the the falling cost of drones, so jammers will be outnumbered on the field.

So what you're going to get is a counter-missile that's simply a drone that homes in on the location of a jammer and when it looses signal suicide bombs the last known position of the signal to take out the antenna. Such a device would have a large range and provide overlapping support for drone operators.

>>57083130

The Taliban did not have six aircraft carriers. Counter-insurgency is very expensive and it doesn't always work. Insurgents don't need complex logistics chains either, because by definition they are not a standing army of an established state. You can have six aircraft carriers and a globe threatening nuclear arsenal and lose to impoverished guerillas, because fighting is actually only a small part of the war.

What makes the difference in guerilla success, from the American Revolution to Vietnam, is public opinion. People don't realize what "hearts and minds" really means, that's most of the war.

The American people, the soldiers themselves, all of them knew the war was wrong. So Biden pulled out and the Taliban won. Like how the Brits pulled out and America won the revolution. The Brits could have stayed in the Americas, they had an overwhelming force and massive military supremacy. They just lost the will to fight, because the Patriots would not give up until they won their freedom. They wore them down with guerilla tactics, it was a prolonged conflict with seemingly no end for the British.

So they just gave up. It wasn't worth it. The people were sick of the war, and their power is derived from the mandate of the people.

It wasn't some Bronze Age contest of who can stab the most guys, it was public opinion in London that caused the Brits to cease operations in America and surrender. That is modern warfare.

>SAN DIEGO — It’s lunchtime aboard the nuclear attack submarine Jefferson City and the tired crew -- some bearing fresh grease stains on their work overalls -- fills the tiny dining room, clearly ready to chow down.

Except it's bullshit, heavier projectiles lose less kinetic energy at range. The Spit actually went with 20+.50 cause 2*20 didn't fit even though it was preferred. The 20 and .50 were judged to have similar ballistic properties, so it was a .50 to replace the 2 .303s.

Not only that, a .50 losing its energy loses its effect, a 20 still goes boom.

The "grenade lobbers" were the low muzzle energy 30s of the Germans, but those could rip a B-17 apart. The 20s were the best all rounders and the .50 was just junk, heavy for little target effect, wing mounted for convergence problems. It just worked cause the American planes had enough engine power and barely armoured to unarmoured opposition. But with 20s it would have been lighter and quicker for same firepower or better armed for same weight, saving tons of American lives.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57098153
How much did you pay for all that, and did you get the coax cable as well?

As for using any of it. First of all, do not turn on that radio in the OP without an antenna hooked up to it. If you accidentally key it up without an antenna you will burn out the finals. Second of all, getting a license isn't optional with the radio in the OP if you want to transmit. HF is not plug and play like the radios that commonly get talked about here, and the only way to truly learn how to use it is by actually making contacts with other people over it. I'd recommend studying for a general class amateur radio license since it covers voice and data modes while the lower technician class license only covers morse code.

How much use you can get out of this one: >>57098232 depends on your area. Again, don't turn it on without an antenna hooked up, and don't try to talk to people on the amateur radio bands without a license as they don't like that. You can check on repeaterbook.com for 2 meter repeaters in your area to see if there's any significant activity, along with on the 2 meter calling frequency (146.520 MHz), and any websites for amateur radio clubs in your area to see if there's another designated local simplex frequency along with the dates and times they might host nets. Don't try to scan entire amateur radio bands as your radio will not scan fast enough for you not to miss what little activity there is. The 2 meter and 70 cm band are pretty dead where I live outside of scheduled nets, storm chasers, and one repeater that's basically linked to an internet voice chat service.

I'd honestly recommend asking on >>>/diy//HAM/
