Old Cover New Thread
Resource on what these spec terminology mean
https://www.nite-walker.com/post/2019/11/21/specs-for-dummies-101
https://apollogearco.com/blogs/news/night-vision-specs-explained
https://gloomgroup.com/blogs/night-vision-info/night-vision-specifications-understanding-what-they-mean

You shouldn't be chasing for spec values but they do exist and if you wanted to know what "better spec" values are there's a way to know which unit is desirable over another.
Most retailers won't post this info as they build NVDs to order, first come first serve, and depending on their grading scale of high, mid, low tier it may differ from retailers. If a retailer offer a “ready to ship” fully built units they will list the spec values. Hand select is an option from retailers that will try to match to your spec requirements.

Some reputable retailers:
https://www.jrhenterprises.com/
https://nvisionoptics.com/
https://www.customnightvision.com/
https://gooningear.com/
https://apollogearco.com
https://blackphasetactical.com/
https://steeleindustries.com/

SNR: signal to noise ratio, the amount of signal the tube can make compared to the noise
EBI: equivalent background information, how much false image appears in the screen through which the actual image has to show, sort of a noise floor of sorts
Halo: How big the circle of bloom is around lights
Photocathode Sensitivity: How sensitive the photocathode is
LP Resolution: Line pair res of the center of the image as measure against a standardized chart

If one spec is shit it negates the rest, if you have a halo of 2.0 it kinda fucks on an EBI of 0.20 if you want to do any kind of shooting and it's all a balance game

The numbers to meet or beat are
EBI under 1, preferably under 0.6 being great, 0.1 is gucci
Halo under 1, anything under 0.7 is awesome
SNR, over 25 anything over 30 is gucci
Photocathode, 1900+ is pretty great, 2500+ is stellar
Resolution of 64+ is good, 72+ is gucci

posts.com:
>>57028689
>>57028867
Tested the arc bridge last night, did a short sprint just to see if it will hold up from the position I set it to and it held up fine so far.
I decided to allow the bridge to do the widest FOV as it was very manageable to get the pano view to merge in my brain and man in it really is a nice feature to have when you are navigating, looking from a standard 40 degree bino setup at a few houses from the park roughly 50-75yds away I was seeing 3 houses and switching to pano FOV it allowed me to see about 2 houses extra to the left and right side, the blending of the two tubes is like looking at a venn diagram and it does take some time to get used to it for me it took about 10-20 seconds to adjust a bit of the arms to get the right position to allow me to get used to the merging of the images after that I was able to walk around like I normally can with mono or standard bino configurations.
I vastly prefer three arc bridge over the panobridge, it was simple to just pull apart the arms to get into pano view vs the panobridge requiring to get the right angle for both arms and it basically giving you unlimited adjustments it was harder to get the right placement and also it loosens over time quickly so you have to readjust quite often.
Using the Jerry-C/COTI was interesting, in the standard bino confusion the thermal overlay looked similar to how it looked in a mono confusion meaning my brain merged the two images. Once I set the pano FOV the thermal tube and non thermal tube split the display and my brain was able to tell the two tube display apart.
Unfortunately my NVGR recorder didn't record any video footage and I don't know why, I took out the sd card to see if there's any new video files and maybe the old video files that were already on there from a prior recording session caused it to not record as files existed already, but I deleted those files and did a simple test and the camera did record in that test, so I dunno.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57041944
Another thing, I decided to go with the metal flat screws to have the units able to be adjusted closer as the thumbscrew protrudes a lot.

Overall I like this bridge and it's a good one to buy if anyone is interested in going dual pvs-14s to get a pano view. I'm gonna do further test with actual weapon use and see how it handles that.

I know on the PVS-14 you can look at the eyepiece lens and turn the diaopter to a specific power value, for me its around -1.5 to -2.5, and look around at a specific angle to get the reflection hit the lens to see the intensifier model name, I'll try my best to get a picture of my tube through the eyepiece lens.
This image is pretty blurry, but it was difficult to get a picture of the model number but I was able to get like half of the "L3" logo and two letters of "Made in USA" text. >Wraith wouldn't turn back on after being stored in the cold (15 degrees Fahrenheit at the coldest) after a failed coyote stake out.
>Fresh Energizer lithium batteries, stored alongside the optic. No power.
>Tried a USB power bank that I knew was good. No power.
>Brought it back inside, let it warm up and put in warm but not fresh cr123s. Oh hey it powers on.
Got a lolosun circle dot coming to replace it on my WASR.
I do like the Wraith, had a bunch of folks shoot with it over the weekend during the day. They all had a similar report, it is different but neat. I think it would be better on a softer gun than a 7.62x39mm. Gonna use it for my AR-15 build. Which I will hopefully get the parts for the upper ordered over the weekend.
Also, the SMSlaser from amazon is holding up well so far. The down and dirty splicing of an airshit tape switch hasn't failed or melted.
NGL, I want to get that Vulcan surefire head before attempting to replace the white light of the SMSlaser with an IR head. I really like how small the SMS is. It just has a few glaring problems preventing it from being a near perfect, civilian power MFAL.
>Swap the multi pin connector and tape switch for a proper Crane style plug receptacle.
>Replace the white light head for a focusable IR lamp or laser illuminator.
>Replace and/or relocate the on/off push button switch with a larger momentary only.
>Replace some of the settings on the selection dial to reflect the replaced white light. Don't need an IR strobing weapon light, IMO.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The Pard NV007A came in. It works really well as a digital night vision device. Obviously it needs an IR illuminator to be useful. The built in one is fine, but the separate one I ordered that has a focus ring works better. I haven’t had a chance to see how it works as a sight. I have noticed the reticle isn’t perfectly centered with the clip on. Idk how this will affect accuracy, but I’ll find out. It has some neat features like being able to record your shots as well as a jack for a microphone and the ability to synch audio to the video. It can also record in color with enough white light. It also automatically adjusts the frame rate based on how much IR it is receiving. I guess this was done to improve performance in low light, but it’s honestly kind of annoying. It has a QD feature. You clamp the sleeve to the scope, and the clip on attaches to the sleeve with some lugs and a latch. It seems to be worth the $220 I paid for it. The sensor is far and away better than the night fox cape. The screen resolution is also much higher, and when there is plenty of IR it appears to have a much smoother image even though the manual lists it at 30 fps. I wish Pard would make a head mountable monocular with this sensor, screen and a flood illuminator. I would pick it up asap at this price point. Finally, unlike the nightfox it can pick up vis lasers no problem.

>>57093744
>0 and 1 tubes require an insane amount of light. even bright moonlight isnt quite enough
Gen 0 required IR floodlights. Gen 1, however, does work by bright moonlight. In Vietnam it required the cascade tube design. Today it only requires 1 tube. But I think you're still right because while gen 1 does work and show you more than you can see under a bright moon, it's no where near as bright as gen 2/3. Gen 3 has to dial back (gating/ABC) under bright moon conditions, and is still incredibly bright.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57096887
Accurate, bolting it to the building frame is the only way to make it as secure *as it can be*, but you aren't doing that in an off-campus rental. The 100 lb safe hidden in a cabinet or closet is the most compromise you should realistically expect to decide on once you've weighed all the pros and cons of each option.

Hiding it, whether in a disguised container or taped under the bed or any other infinitely clever idea, works up until the moment someone decides to just turn over the room, which for a roommate is *hopefully* never, but for a burglar is always.

A defensive handgun only works when you have it so the goal is to have it, on you, not in your backpack, as many hours of the day as is feasible. I absolutely get wanting to chill in your boxers, you're not fucking Jason Bourne, you don't have to be on all the time. The stated goal is to keep this fact from your roommates. Form a habit of unlocking the safe as you dress and stick to it always. 7 days a week you put on your pants and put on your gun, in that order, with nothing in between, interruptions will likely be nonexistent but don't let them derail this process.

Having a bedside gun is great if your bedroom is a secure room, meaning you have a key lock on the door and it stays locked. This is how you do things when you have kids so pay attention. Yes, you should always be ready if you accept the responsibility in the first place, but if your roommates can get into your bedroom while you're asleep, this stops being an option. You at least need a fast access safe, and when you walk out the door, the whole thing should have gone in a real safe. Biometric fast access safes have been circumvented by everything under the sun, a code safe that works exactly the same as your phones lock screen is what you want.

Sorry for the wall of text but I wanted to cover several important points.

>>57098648
There is something actually worse than a casaba howitzer, I think.

Macroparticles, like dust, have lots of surface area to gather charge relative to their mass. A sand caster is kinda like the step between a coil gun (big slugs) and a typical particle accelerator (superheated gas) in terms of velocity. If you could mass produce complex structures with huge amounts of surface area like this for a gun, you'd basically be able to throw buckets of sand at 10,000,000+ m/s. If a single dust grain hits that that speed, you might drill a millimeter or two into a slab of metal, but there is also a million particles lined up right behind it. That isn't the scary part though.

If you're able to make this kind of ammo, you could also give it *payloads*. Hollow out a dust size particle, and sit some weapon grade uranium or a deuterium-tritium core inside it. It will go nuclear upon hitting a target at those speeds, putting out 100+ times the energy you put into it. It'd be like a tsar bomba machine gun you could slice asteroids in half with.

>>57097347
>I assume "kill all the dumbass scientists" is a mission goal but it could be achieved in better ways
Maybe not, at least if you go by OpFor but there's some evidence for this in HL1 too. Earlier on there was an attempt to work with BMRF staff and security, but eventually this broke down and most of the grunts just began shooting everything on sight after the situation got bad enough. You get the idea that they were at the least meant to capture the scientists, if not just evac them. Factor in that most of the blame for the resonance cascade would be on Black Mesa's shoulders (particularly Gordon's) and many of them probably chose to quietly abandon their official orders and take matters into their own hands. In mentioning the blame that Gordon would have in their eyes, consider that HECU actually did capture him once. They were supposed to bring him in for questioning, instead the two grunts decided to kill him in a trash compactor of their own accord and lie about it to their CO later.
Overall it seems more like a botched operation if anything else, HECU went in without any idea what they would be up against (not that they could have feasibly known) and got fucked hard as such. There was probably some degree of mistrust between their commanders and most of the infantry as the crisis went on, think Vietnam. Incompetent leadership and grunts who were sick of it all lashing out at the people they could kill largely consequence-free due to the fragmented nature of their forces.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>57098093
I work from home, and I do most of my reloading then, so it's already worth it. Even if I didn't reload at work, I'd still save a ton of money.

I shoot about 20k 9mm a year, here's how I break it down:
>Factory ammo at 30 cpr * 20k = $6k
vs
>Handloads at 15 cpr = $3k
I average 600 rounds/hour on a Dillon 550, so 20k rounds would take me a little over 33 hours to reload. Effectively, I save 3k for 34 hours of work, so I effectively make $88/hr to reload. And that's only 9mm, which has the lowest cost savings per round that I reload.

Why rights and laws and all that jazz are how they are start making a lot more sense when you realize that there is no higher authority than violence and the state monopolizes violence with the consent of (most of) the people given some conditions (rights). Without the ability to wage adequate violence in retaliation, your rights mean nothing, and rights as we know them today are nothing but a promise that the state will do the hard work for you, in exchange for your recognition on it's monopoly on violence, that you will not enact violence upon the state itself.

Nothing PHYSICALLY stops you from attempting to fund your own nuclear program, to not recognize the sovereignty of the state and instead uphold your own... save for the fact that sovereign entities answer to nobody but themselves, and there's nothing stopping the state from, when all the terminology and wordplay is put aside, declaring war and conquering your insignificant one-man autocracy. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57087115
Look at the Keltec RDB, which isn't free floated but uses the rail to stiffen the barrel as a case of how going against free floating can help. For another example you take a non free floated firearm and exert force onto the structural parts then you'll experience POI shifts from where you're sighted, like with the M4s that don't have a FF handgrip. What free floating the barrel does is it makes it so you're dealing only with barrel resonance that is isolated from the rest of the gun and by extension the shooter's grip. If the foregrip can deal with the forces of resting on a bipod, being held at different points which can shift the resonance node of the barrel and being pushed up against a window then that increases accuracy. However when you're looking at an autocannon installation that doesn't really apply since they're not resting the cannon against surfaces and the only load path is going into the mount. What that stiffener structure does is that it makes the barrel's virtual diameter a little bigger in that it acts like a pretend taper barrel. You can find examples of this in small arms with carbon fiber encased barrels or "hollow" barrels that look like water jackets but use the larger diameter to increase stiffness.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57089544
>>57089544
If you want a HMMWV as a daily driver you had better be prepared to do a lot of work on it. Most all of the HMMWV on govplanet have had parts robbed off them and are at best 80% complete. Expect to go through fuel system/ cooling system/ steering and suspension before it is remotely reliable. The electrical system on these trucks is 24v.
They don’t actually take a key. There is a cable under dash you can lock steering wheel with. You can add a keyed switch to interrupt the signal to fuel shutoff solenoid or neutral safety switch in order to disable the truck when you’re not with it.

I’m averaging around 10 MPG with the old 3speed trans and 42inch tires. Top speed is 67 mph. You can technically go faster than 67mph but you are over speeding the engine and you can’t do it for long.

The original 6.2 and 6.5 engines are underpowered for such a large heavy truck. They did this on purpose to keep young kids from tearing them up needlessly. They have plenty of torque due to gearing though.

My advice is to get a newer 2000+ HMMWV like an m1123 with the 4speed transmission. They drive a lot better than the 3speeds. However the 4speed 4L80 trans uses a 12v controller for shifting and that is one more thing you will have to deal with.

Picture is of the 200A dual voltage generator for a HMMWV.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57092001
I’m going to say you would need a specialized mechanic. They are unlike any other vehicle.

The brakes are mounted to center differential.
The center differential are torsen type differential.
The wheel hubs are portal gear reduction hubs.
It has a spring applied hydraulic released fan clutch.
It has a 24volt electrical system.
It has a generator instead of an alternator.
There isn’t a single fuse on the entire truck… unless you count the ground shunt. It does have a few resetting circuit breakers.

Pretty much every tech manual for the HMMWV is available for free online, but it is still hard to get information that everyone agrees on. For example, adjusting the shift modulator on the 3speed is all mechanical. I haven’t been able to find any reliable information on correct procedure for adjustment and just kind of played with it until it felt correct.

Picture sort of related. It’s a fresh DB2 injection pump and a set of injectors for my HMMWV I plan on installing this spring.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57092223
The reason I have a fresh injection pump and injectors is because I started noticing the engine would crank over a few extra times when it was at full operating temp. This combined with incorrect batteries that were too small for the truck left me stranded one time. I was able to dump some cold water on injection pump and then it fired right up. This is a sign of wear in injection pump and not building enough pressure to pop injectors when hot. I ordered a new starter and found some of the correct Hawker 6TL batteries and it has essentially resolved the issue, but being a mechanic I still felt the need to replace fuel system.

Field service technician on heavy equipment. I mostly work on hydraulics and electronics, including emission systems in all the new tier 4 stuff. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>57094675
NTA and you'll have to check Michigan law specifically, but by federal standards on this shouldn't matter in the slightest. I don't think there's any "record" even on denials, because why would it even matter? Every single instant check is run over again each time and it's based on data on you they've got in terms of criminal records and such, "denials" can happen for all sorts of reasons that have nothing to do with something that would actually make it unlawful for you to have a gun. Input errors and people who are new and don't know how to use the system is just a fact of it and has been from the beginning. For purchasing a regular firearm, you just need to deal with the federal background check normally and fed rules, and if your state also requires other ID or permit presentation they'd do that at the FFL level. Then if you have additional registration if needed.

But again, this is all assuming a regular Title 1 firearm. If it's a Title 2 NFA weapon, including if you're planning to make one, you need to follow that process. Even getting the parts without prior approval is a felony so don't do that.
